I would not recommend this to anyone who likes RPG's, story driven games or even the fallout universe. I would recommend it to someone who likes fps shooters and looter shooter survival/ base building games and are willing to button smash over incredibly stupid dialogue that is used as an excuse to go somewhere, kill a bunch of things and bring something back, press a button etc.

So the upsides in context of previous fallout games: The engine is much better and smoother than the one in previous 3D fallout games.  That's pretty much it.

Negatives: The world makes no sense and is considerably dumber than in previous fallout games, even compared to FO3. There is zero role play, you get to choose some stats but at the end of day, you'll just go from a to b to shoot stuff. The plot is incredibly boring, linear and poorly written. There is no fun dialogue options and everything is read out in a generic bland voice that is about as interesting as jar of pickles. 

It's not a bad game by any means, it's just a really horrible fallout game.

Terrible game, nothing works anymore.
All DLC's except High Resolution Texture Pack will softlock your game if you do any of them before finishing story mode or side quests.
If they do not softlock your game which happened in all of my 3 playthroughs they will make your main game story quests or side quests collide with DLC quests making them overlap and disable certain choices you can make in that DLC or kill characters you can save. *This isn't supposed to happen by disable I mean glitch out

Massive amount of overlapping textures

Non-stopping crashes.

Saves can be easily corrupted.

Do not ever install any free add-ons from the Store, Servers litteraly don't work they will either delete all of the items that have that modifications or corrupt your game file.

Stealing a power armor from a dead enemy will immediately make any settlement hostile towards you even though it's yours don't ever use a looted power armor near a settlement.

Dogmeat and all other companions have terrible AI always hitting walls or invisible walls and always getting stuck at doors and making your movement impossible. In some missions there isn't an option to talk to your companions meaning if your companion gets stuck in a small room with you while it's near the door will litteraly softlock the game since there is no way to trigger the companion follow or command it to go anywhere else.

Terrible combat gameplay experience if you have no previous experience playing this game you will fight your own faction at least 17 times while doing side missions. This is side missions not main faction missions game will eventually make you betray a faction(s) if you mention those there is at least 40+ MAIN not side missions in which you litteraly fight the faction you are allied with again.

The swimming physics and animations look like they were exported from a free unity project.

There is just so many more wrong things about this game that I don't remember since I haven't played it over 2 years.
Buy at your own risk.

I haven't played this game since it came out, and after roughly 10 years, my feelings are mixed, with most of my nostalgia being quickly squashed. While there is much good to this game, there is also a lot that just didn't seem to age well, and other parts of it that were reminders of things I disliked 10 years ago. 

After re-playing FO3 recently, this game feels absurdly easy. Caps in every single nook and cranny of the wastela-Commonwealth, med supplies everywhere, and every single object being expendable for supplies ironically takes the fun out of exploring. There's never really a feeling of satisfaction when you go through a building or a long quest, because you inevitably come out 10x richer and heavier than when you went in. 

Every time I was blown away by the graphics, I would look in another direction at a cartoon-y npc or have to engage in a weirdly cinematic & grandiose conversation. I guess my expectations were a lot higher coming back to this game, and though I will continue to replay it, the motivation is quickly diminishing. 

You could say I'm biased towards FO3/NV, and you would be correct. I miss the entire solar system freezing to engage in conversation, and finding 4 caps and a pack of mentats in a random locker that had an expert-rated lock on it. FO4 is still a fun game, but certainly feels standalone this time around.

Excellent Looter Shooter with RPG-Elements as well as base building in an atmospheric open world which is fun to explore. I'm a first time player... hence there are no nostalgic feelings involved. I definitely understand now why so many people love Bethesda games besides their bugs and occasional bad writing. 

In addition FO 4 is very easy to mod even for a beginner and you can basically modify the game to your liking, the possibilities are endless. There is some Jank here and there but nothing game-ruining.

Even with my currently around 20 mods the game is very stable, so far I did not encounter any crashes or game-breaking bugs (not even minor bugs to be honest).

All in all the game is a big recommendation for everyone who likes Loot, exploring and an atmopsheric post-apocalyptic open world in which there are many things to do but you are not forced to do any of them if you don't like (unlike the more story-driven RPGs like RDR2, KCD2 or CP77 for comparison). I myself prefer the FO4-style RPG much more.

- Main Storyline: pretty mid ngl, like, most generic, run-of-the-mill narrative.

- Side Stories: Abundant, rewarding to complete due to varied loot BUT, redundant they get. They usually are fetch quest followed by escorting whomever or clear X place.

- Game Mechanics: As with each new Fallout game that comes out, they get better and better. - Graphics: Love them, especially the lighting.

- Game Physics: can be summed up by "Great in general, served with a side of Jank, *Bethesda Jank*™"

- Fun to be had: Much.

All in all, I do recommend Fallout 4

Fallout 4 is definitely an interesting title to review for me as if you had asked me about it when I just finished my complete playthrough for it I would have easily not recommended it. Why? For the most part of my 225 hours of experience with the game I was not affected by that many issues like bugs or crashes, but for whatever reason in the last 20 or so hours I spent finishing the final dlc in my playthrough, I faced every bug and glitch that has been the game since the launch of the dlc in 2016. This absolutely ruined my experienced at the end of my playthrough. I am writing this review after a few months to look at the game in general from a fairer perspective which is why I have recommended it in the first place.

Fallout 4 innovates from the previous titles in terms of its gun play and combat getting major overhaul with guns that have a punch to them and unique weapons that are wacky but actually useful. The perks and S.P.E.C.I.A.L. stats getting an overhaul with how skill checks work provided more ways to build a character to your liking. While all this is improved upon, the story of the main game takes a major toll with no longer having serious consequences, basically just oversimplifying some of the major rpg elements that the previous games in the series where able to provide.

One thing that I would like to address about the game is it tries to do so many things and ends up making those things annoying to say the least. The settlement system is a good example of this as at first look it looks overly detailed and well thought out but the longer you spend trying to work with it, you will see all its issues. Because of the game’s original release on older gen system and their lower specs there is a limitation on how many items you can build in a settlement these include farm and beds like essentials and all the non-essential decor items. Even though the game’s had a next gen patch and have been released on newer consoles it still has this limit when the newer hardware is being capable of easily rendering much more items. If want to build a good-looking settlement what you will do is often use the item deletion glitch in the settlement to go over the limit of placeable objects. Another example is the loading screens, every time you go inside a building with a door or fast travel you sit at a loading screen for 4-5 seconds. And yes, it is regardless of how modern or strong your rig is you will have to wait for loading screen. It was the same for Fallout 3 & New Vegas but at least in those if you were playing on a modern system the load screen was instant. This sounds like a minor nitpick but these load screens will add up over the course of your playthrough whether you play for 10 hours or 100 hours.

On my final word about the game is it doesn’t always work the way that it’s supposed to but the bugs & glitches sure do. Then why do I recommend it, all the criticisms that I give the game is because of how good the game can be if Bethesda actually tests these systems instead of spending their time in the creation club. While I don’t touch on the store too much in this review as this was one of the older game releases thus the creation club items are just mediocre cosmetics and two or three overpowered weapon packs from Doom & Skyrim, which are not needed to play the game unlike 76. A normal player that just plays the quests and dlc is not going to find the experience of Fallout 4 bad. I played over 200 hours exploring most if not all of the main story and dlc map locations marked or unmarked without doing any glitches and thus stumbled on all the places that the game falls short or tries to do a lot and end up achieving very little. If you are fine with an okayish Bethesda rpg set in a fallout setting you can give this game a try.

After almost completing everything, I would say that the older games were better in most regards, this one is just slop compared to them. Also, it's crashy and the world feels empty. It did start off good but once your character becomes level 30-40 it becomes a cakewalk. You can practically use power armor the whole game with the right perks, the AI is dumb as bricks, and the hardest difficulty isn't worth shit. Survival is good but only for a while, after that it becomes too easy as the enemies are just as fragile as you, but you're wearing power armor 24/7 so not really fragile.

Addiction, that's the only was to describe it, 100 hours in the first week and well. you can see on this review that I didn't stop, I'm just now touching into mods and the modding community is amazing, the support is wonderful and it's easier to figure out than other games in this series, there is crashing but it's not that bad *unless* you play survival where you can only save by sleeping, I ended up downloading an autosave mod which I really didn't want to have to do, but after losing a few hours of progress I caved.

But don't let that discourage you, crashes are few and far between and expected from a game of this age and complexity, however it can be annoying when it does happen, from what i understand most players don't play survival so you'll likely be fine, but I'm a sucker for punishment as I play exclusively survival.

the DLC's are not that bad all things consider, Nuka-World is worse for wear when you realize that the leather armor is better than Marine armor, it seems they just made nuka world then added +20 to everything as a base stat across the board, making the park a harder place and a nice challenge over all. However it can feel very lazy to just add higher hp pools as a challenge.

Far Harbor is lovely if you are into lore and immersion, being a detective and figuring this out is amazing, especially if you turn off quest markers so you actually have to figure things out on your own-some. 

As for the other DLC, it has issues here and there, but in the end I feel like I got what I paid for, it's not great, but it adds enough that it felt fair.


If you are looking to start the Fallout Series, start here, do not start on 76, 3, or New Vegas. I can't speak for 1 or 2. However this is where you want to start. I hear people complain about their game getting bricked from the "Next-Gen" update, which I agree that update sucks so bad, but I haven't had any issues, that being said I downloaded the game after said update, and if your reading this, so will you. 

Something frustrating about the next gen update is there are some soldiers you can find in power armor at level 1, as fast as you want, it's the best armor in the entire game, this makes building up and fixing the starting armor and all armor after that you find feel worthless.

Depends on mods to make it good. It may be fun, but isn't a good Fallout game. 

Bethesda destroyed the art style of the gritty, undefined wastes, trading it in for cartoon-y, inaccurate, rounded and simplified mess of a AAA game. The 50's environment isn't what it's supposed to be. It was to be retro-futuristic, gritty, destroyed towns, cities, etc. The visuals are nice but they are just too bright and flashy, unlike the raw and gritty visuals of the earlier games.

Bethesda fucked up on the design of guns and enemies. Majority of the guns look like toys and hunks of messes, instead of actual guns. (I'm not counting energy weapons because... well yeah.) The super-mutants now look like skinny Shrek-like guys instead of beasts that were strengthened by the F.E.V., Ghouls now look a lot more "cutesy" and simplified, and Deathclaws are no longer terrifying. They're just big hostile lizards. 

Gameplay wise, it's a disaster. Yes, I know Bethesda was trying to open up to a new audience, but it betrays the original Fallouts in so many ways. Dialogue is shit, ambiguity of your character is gone due to them being voiced and having a very tight backstory, the RPG elements are watered down and diluted to the point where the tasty sodas of the Fallout games before, are now what remains after the ice melts in the soda, a watery mess.

Variety is odd. There isn't much variety between the factions, being that some factions are just guards for Diamond City. They completely scrapped the ammo variants and skills. It's only perks now. No more using points to fill up your speech, lockpick, medicine, etc. 

Story sucks. It may have some thrilling side quests and some small interesting plot points, but it's just so hollow. There's not much complexity to it.

Look, Fallout 4 is a kind of fun game, but it isn't a Fallout game. Bethesda mischaracterized what made Fallout well- Fallout, and made others mischaracterize the franchise.The gameplay itself keeps itself together with duct tape and glue, then calls it a day. I think it's enjoyable but it betrays Fallout in so many ways.  I liked the Power Armor system tho.

Finally, the biggest reason I dislike this game. No 5 hour sex scene between Nick Valentine and Preston Garvey.

Like Skyrim, I have an unhealthy amount of hours on this game across all consoles, roughly 2500-3000. This game is a comfortable 2nd place on the favorite-games-heavily-lenient-on-nostalgia-also-released-by-Bethesda List. This game is rich with lore, its neck and neck with Elder Scrolls for me. Gameplay is amazing, best Gun Combat out of any fallout entry. I love the Physics and Character movement of this game, its so fluid and intuitive. Story Wise, like where you yourself go/do, is all right. The broader lore and story at large however is fantastic, and thats What I care about most in this game. The Alternative-History Genre is one of my favorites in any media, and Fallout to me is the Poster boy of that. The ultimate end of humanity, A nuclear wasteland filled with other Sci-Fi elements that are clearly fiction, but you can visualize how they could of become reality had our scientists and political leaders make different decisions. Its a Mockery of the Modern Hyper-Militarized, Pro War Sentiment that we all confide to everyday. One day, society will destroy itself, but Humanity will still be standing.

For context, I have attempted to complete this game four times in total. I would usually get five hours in before getting bored out of my mind and uninstalling. However, as time went by I became more patient and were more willing to put up with inconveniences such as loading screens or walking simulators (sometimes the game would leave you loading for up to four minutes and it surprised me the first time because I was sure the game had crashed).

I started getting more enjoyment when I changed my play-style so that rather then leveling by clearing out random locations, I chose to listen to each character's dialogue so that I get more attached and involved in the story, and as a bonus, completing quests are rewarded with XP.

I didn't play through the game all in one blast, I would switch between games just playing whatever was more interesting at the moment and I eventually got to the end of this one. You just gotta learn to ignore some side quests and mix up the monotony of gameplay with a main story line quest.

In all honesty though, the very ending of the game gave me a sour taste in my mouth because it just ends, the game didn't give me any closure that I made "right" or "wrong" decisions in gameplay because it just leaves me to figure that out myself. The only thing you get is if you go around the various towns you can hear the casual dialogue of characters reacting to the changes that were made, but it is still extremely underwhelming.

----

Extra note: Game doesn't run very smooth until you change the .ini files which takes a bit of reading in forums before you get right which is just an extra headache that I would rather not deal with
FUN FUN FUN GAME GAME GAME

Nearly 300 hours of play time, and that's on the steam version alone. I owned this on the Xbox when it first released, and again when I swapped to the Ps4. On each of them I played easily as many hours. Needless to say, I love this game.
The FPS aspect is fun and well done. It's a different kind of game from say Call of Duty or any of the other popular FPS games. It's not online or competitive. You're playing through a story contained within a fairly open world. It can be fast paced and epic, or as slow and stealthy as you want, depending on your play style.

It has a nice "builders" function where you're able to upgrade weapons and armor, and probably should just to maintain an edge in combat. There is a neat settlement feature which I've always enjoyed building within. It even has a "time stop" feature that gives combat a bit more of a "turn-based" feel, which can be fun though I rarely utilize it. I enjoy the run-n-gun.

What has me coming back time and time again is the story. I've explored most-all of the various branches, but I still enjoy running through my favorite story branch now and then, even if it's not exactly canon. So it has it's own "cyoa" aspect. Fans of this game will have different opinions on what should be the "correct" ending (even if Bethesda has already stated which is canonical).

My most beloved game of all time. It has crafting, building, modifications, firearms, melee combat, iconic characters, an amazing perk tree, great extension pack that give you amazing to hilarious storylines. 
Sadly, it does have a horrible start. I carried more about a boy locked in a refrigerator for 200 years, than my own son. 
Still amazing and I will play this game for as long as I can.

Fallout 4 was my first Fallout game. I still remember watching H20 Delirious play all those years ago. 

So far, gunplay feels fun and fresh, the dialogue is good enough and pretty enjoyable, building settlements has become an addiction, I have become a sociopath in conversations, and it could just be me but it appears another settlement needs my help. 

I started with vanilla plus modded taking into account the age of the game (mostly mods for QoL and preventing crashing/aiding stability) and I loved it so much. PC bricked before I could fully explore all the side quests but man am I going to copy back my save once I get a replacement. It is a game that has aged very well and will continue to age so. Definitely recommend the game if you're looking to play a Fallout game and love the retro Atompunk post wasteland aesthetic.

Will definitely also try out Fallout 3 and New Vegas at some point considering how fun playing this one was!

1. What do you do when you hear a "click" and then everything goes white?
🔲 A. Duck. It's just a flashbang.
🔲 B. Shout "MINI NUKE!!" and surrender.
✅ C. Take a screenshot first, then panic.
🔲 D. Send a final message to Dogmeat.

2. How do you resolve a conflict between factions?
🔲 A. Cold-hearted diplomacy.
✅ B. Mini-nuke in the middle of a meeting.
🔲 C. Sneak in and steal all the ammo.
🔲 D. Join all the factions. Then you're confused.

3. Who's your favorite companion?
🔲 A. Piper, the idealistic journalist.
🔲 B. Danse, the Power Armor brother.
✅ C. Dogmeat, because he never complains.
🔲 D. Trashcan Carla. Always showing up at the wrong time.

4. What's your most emotional moment?
🔲 A. Finding your child.
🔲 B. Having to sacrifice a faction you love.
✅ C. Seeing a Brahmin stuck on the roof of a 3rd-story house.
🔲 D. Getting a critical hit from an angry Mr. Handy.

5. You see a Deathclaw at the end of the street. What do you do?
🔲 A. Run in the opposite direction.
🔲 B. Put on your Power Armor, ready for battle.
🔲 C. Throw a grenade while singing "Country Roads".
✅ D. Quick Save first. Then fight. If you die, reload.

6. Are you comfortable with the Brotherhood of Steel?
🔲 A. Yes, they protect technology.
✅ B. No, they look like gym guys who like to carry tanks.
🔲 C. Maybe, but they rarely shower.
🔲 D. I think they're a failed boy band.

7. Have you ever ridden a Vertibird BOS? Your reaction?
🔲 A. "Wow, cool!"
✅ B. "Why does the enemy have a Missile Launcher every time I get on it?!"
🔲 C. "Is this Uber?"
🔲 D. "I wanted to tour around but instead I got shot at."

8. How do you feel when you see the quest map?
🔲 A. Excited.
✅ B. Dizzy: There are 38 markers & 7 overlapping quests.
🔲 C. Panic: I don't know who this quest is from.
🔲 D. Cynical Laughter: Everyone ends up being told to clear the factory of Raiders.

9. You've only been playing the dungeon for an hour. Then...
🔲 A. Quick save.
✅ B. Game crash.
🔲 C. You accidentally pressed quick load to 3 hours ago.
🔲 D. An NPC gets stuck in the toilet and asks you to help him out.

10. What did Fallout 4 teach you?
🔲 A. Survival skills.
✅ B. Don't trust old buildings — there are traps in the ceiling.
🔲 C. The best coping mechanism is loot.
🔲 D. Life is tough, especially in Survival mode without Fast Travel.

- 0–2 answers  ✅ = Still a Vault resident. Get out first, sniff out Radroaches.
- 3–4 answers  ✅ = Wastelander level "Loves Loot, Fears Deathclaws"
- 5–6 answers  ✅ = True Survivor. The Minutemen are looking for you every day.
- 7-10 answers ✅ = You are Preston Garvey.

I do love this game but after 16 hours the problems outweigh the enjoyment.

I love the Skyrim of the future vibes, the humour is perfect and the story is very interesting. The America of the 50s vibe is perfect and whats left in the wasteland is great.

But loading times are a joke, they were taking 2-8 minutes to load a level when you exit/enter a buliding. I found a mod to cut this down a little bit but it never drops below 2 mins. It breaks the story completely sitting looking at a loading screen (I have SSD, 16 Gb Ram & an RTX4070).

Then walking, it's so slow, my god i thought AC Valhalla was bad this is a whole new level.

It's always the little things that ruin a good game and 16 hours was my limit. It's cheap but those loading times, lack of direction in the story just broke me.

I love Skyrim, Odyseey, Origins, Hellblade, Placid Plastic Duck Simulator so slow is my bag.

I cannot remember the state of the game when I played it originally, back in early 2016. I used mods and stuck with the Institute, but never bothered to finish the achievements. Flash forward to now, and I am not sure if the game has improved. 

This playthrough was based on the un-modded version of the game. The loading times range from a couple of seconds to nearly a minute, and with everything being isolated in their own areas, you are going to be seeing those loading screens often. It kills the flow of the game considerably and starts to become more noticeable. Path-finding can be incredibly frustrating with NPCs just standing still after being activated for a quest or taking forever to start moving after hitting the corner of a door, as if the programming is struggling to compensate. Thankfully, I had only three cases where I needed load a safe to retry the section to get them to move, but the amount of downtime this creates is beyond irritating. Then there is the wonkiness of your own movement, whether in a suit of power armor or standard. You could be moving forward, then suddenly the locomotion shifts to the side and no amount of course correction can eliminate the drifting sensation. There are even times the character will just randomly strafe from side to side when you are trying to make a turn or backing up. I cannot remember the last time I experienced this in a game. Then you have the way dialog tracking is cut off when you initially start dialog, which makes it difficult to skip it without risking accidentally shooting your weapon into them and requiring a reload. It is bad enough NPCs will start talking to you without a prompt and trap you in a dialog choice screen when all you were doing was trying to sit down or wait for a NPC to finish walking to your location.

There are a slew of bugs ranging from items not spawning properly, enemies disappearing into the terrain, objectives not updating properly, and doors leading to a new area not working properly. Thankfully the game ran better than I expected with consistent frame rates, but there are times the game did crash (only a few times).

This is more of a case of justifying the experience. With how much the system struggles and the amount of time you are forced to wait for subpar combat and the blatant settlement padding, I just can't recommend it. If the story and side content was better (subjective), but even with the two major DLCs being fresh content for me, it really left little in the way of any lasting impression. The Far Harbor was too bogged down by further synth arguments and the Nuka World content had very little in the way of character development (also bogged down by more settlement padding). Some of the companions are great, but the majority felt very flat-line, and the heavy focus on synths can be a huge turn off (depends on your stance on empathy toward machines and the lack of tension due to how they are handled in the setting). 

I just can't recommend it for the technical issues. If you think the story will be interesting, only grab it on a steep sale (which happens often enough), but realize there can be a lot of downtime between action.

P.S. If you are just after the achievements, be prepared for an annoying grind for the tickets at the Nuka-cade (unless you use the console commands, but no clue if that voids achievements)

It is so fun to create a character and run around in the world. Its in my eyes a beautiful game and the music always gets me. The characters are interesting and missions are interesting. Hours upon hours of time in, i never get enough of coming back and playing.
